He called out ‚Äúhuman/animal hybrids).  While I‚Äôve not seen proof of the extremes of what he claimed, we have seen human cells be out in to pig embryo.  So‚Ä¶ at least half right.    He called out weather modification.  Yes, it was publicly disclosed as early as the 1950s. But back then, you trusted the government, right?  And the science was likely less understood and overall, less known by the masses.  He made it widely known, which in my opinion is a great thing. Comment: I really really don't want to give credence to someone like Alex Jones, but I also really really don't want our reason to be tainted by logical fallacies.  It is true that Jones has made claims that were near impossible to prove. It is true that the bombastic way he speaks lends itself to major problems and if he wants to be taken seriously, he needs to be far more careful with his words. It is true he has made some false claims.  But it is also true that he has been right about many things that few are willing to talk about. It is also true that Jones has explained some of his hyperbole or his weird ways of saying things. Like he should just say "I suspect there is a pedophile ring. Here is the evidence," rather than talking about psychic vampires and shit.  The things he has been right about and the things he has rightfully called out I have never seen any pundits, left or right call out. He was the only person I know of who talked about The Bilderberg Group, and whether it is a devious group of people plotting take over of the world or whether it is just a meeting of very powerful individuals, the people ought to know about it, especially if attendance by our own leaders is not disclosed to the people (which violates certain laws).  He told us about the Chinese social credit score system and he was right. He told us about organ harvesting in China and he was right. He told us about organ harvesting in Africa and he was right. He told us about Bohemian Grove, which the people ought to know about. He uncovered odd details about 9/11, and while he didn't get all the facts, he certainly correctly pointed to some suspicious details of the attack and also how bad the Patriot Act was.  The point is that it is a logical fallacy to discredit the person rather than the argument. That is what people are doing with Jones. He also got supremely fucked over by the courts. He did not get his due process, they just steam rolled him. You can despise him, but he is due a fair trial.
